In situ fabrication of nickel-based layered double hydroxides catalysts with carboxymethyl chitosan as biomass template for hydrogenation Jingru Qin 1 Huiling Zhang 1 Haofei Sun Yansu Wang Libo Niu Xingwang Lan ⁎ Guoyi Bai ⁎ Key Laboratory of Chemical Biology of Hebei Province, College of Chemistry and Environmental Science, Hebei University, Baoding, 071002, PR China Key Laboratory of Chemical Biology of Hebei Province College of Chemistry and Environmental Science Hebei University Baoding 071002 PR China Key Laboratory of Chemical Biology of Hebei Province, College of Chemistry and Environmental Science, Hebei University, Baoding 071002, P.R. China. ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 Authors Jingru Qin and Huiling Zhang contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract Herein, we have facilely fabricated a series of novel nickel-based layered double hydroxides catalysts with carboxymethyl chitosan as sacrificial template using an in situ method. A Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ catalyst shows excellent catalytic performance in benzophenone selective hydrogenation. The addition and elimination of CMC was confirmed to play an important role in increasing the BET specific surface area and improving the dispersion of the active Ni species. Furthermore, the strong interaction between the active species and support was also enhanced, simultaneously. These behaviors are believed to promote the catalytic efficiency and suppress the unexpected Ni aggregation. Considering its good catalytic performance and low cost, it has vast potential significance in the fabrication of nickel-based layered double hydroxides catalysts for catalytic reactions. Keywords Nickel-based Layered double hydroxides Carboxymethyl chitosan Hydrogenation Benzophenone 1 Introduction Nickel, one important member of non-noble metal family, is regarded as a promising candidate for replacing noble metals due to its excellent hydrogenation performance, earth-abundant nature and low cost. Thus, design and fabrication of nickel-based catalysts have attracted increasing interests in recent years [1,2]. Various nickel-based catalysts have been applied into many chemical processes, especially catalytic hydrogenation [3–10]. For instance, Wang et al. have prepared a Ni/SiO2-AEH catalyst using an ammonia evaporation hydrothermal (AEH) strategy for the hydrogenation of guaiacol [11]. Our group has fabricated a novel sandwich-like magnetic core-shell nickel-based nano-catalyst (Fe3O4@nSiO2@NiPd-PVP@mSiO2) for cinnamic acid hydrogenation [12]. Nevertheless, most of those nickel-based catalysts in hand still have certain drawbacks, such as aggregating or sintering easily, which is the main reason of poor stability. Therefore, facile fabrication of efficient nickel-based catalysts is a crucial challenge. Recently, two-dimensional layered double hydroxides (LDHs) have attracted significant interest in electrochemistry, medicine, environment and catalysis because of their good stability and structural controllability [13–19]. However, it is still much difficult to control surface area and pore structure of the unique sheet-like structure [20]. Therefore, rational design and preparation of LDHs materials with specific structures are of great importance for improving their catalytic performance. Recently, adding template or intercalation agent during the preparation of LDHs is regarded as a useful method to fabricate active catalysts [21–25]. For instance, Sun et al. have applied sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) as a template and intercalating agent to prepare a 3D flower-like Mg-Al-LDH by a hydrothermal method [26]. To date, most templates still focus on the sulfur-containing substances, which are difficult to be removed after inserting into the layers of LDHs, it is thus very energy-consuming, operation troublesome and environment unfriendly in their preparation process [27]. From the sustainable perspective, selection of green and extensive biomass as template is perhaps one available choice to resolve this issue. Thus, it is highly attractive to develop novel LDHs catalysts via those naturally renewable biomass materials. Among the important biomass materials, chitosan [composed of β-(1,4)-2-acetamido-D-glucopyranose and β-(1,4)-2-amino-D-glucopyranose] is a natural polysaccharide obtained from crustaceans, and a primary derivative of chitin [28–31]. Owing to its excellent biocompatibility and low toxicity, it has been applied into various fields, e.g. agriculture, medicine, food, biosensor and bio-chemical industry [32–36]. However, the solubility of chitosan in neutral and alkaline systems is very poor due to their strong hydrogen bonding, which limits its further applications [37]. Carboxymethyl chitosan (CMC), prepared by introducing a water-soluble carboxyl group into chitosan, can solve this solubility problem of chitosan and then provide a potential way for catalysis. In the past years, some interesting materials have been prepared by means of carboxymethyl chitosan [38–40], but most cases still show some drawbacks more or less [41–44]. In addition, there is still no report about the fabrication of 3D LDHs catalysts via carboxymethyl chitosan as biomass template. Inspired by these considerations, we herein develop a facile and green strategy to construct nickel-based LDHs catalyst with high BET specific surface area and pore structure using biomass carboxymethyl chitosan as template by means of the important “chelate effect”. That is to say that the amino group and hydroxyl group of CMC can coordinate with nickel ions to avoid the rapid precipitation of nickel ions and alkali source during the formation of LDHs. Furthermore, CMC, as a sacrificial template, can promote the exposure of more active sites during the calcination of the LDHs precursor to the mixed metal oxide (LDO), which is in favor of the increase of catalytic performance [45,46]. The preparation procedure of the NiMgAl-CMC-in situ catalyst is depicted in Scheme. 1 . The resulting catalyst reveals excellent catalytic performance in the selective hydrogenation of benzophenone to diphenylmethanol, an important fine chemical intermediate [47–49]. A series of characterizations indicates that the addition and removal of CMC play an important role in increasing the BET specific surface area and improving the dispersion of the active Ni species. Furthermore, the strong interaction between the active species and support was also enhanced, simultaneously, which not only promote the catalytic efficiency but also suppress the Ni aggregation. Therefore, this study provides a useful strategy for fabricating novel nickel-based catalysts with biomass templates for catalytic hydrogenation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Except for special instructions, the purity of all reagents is analytical. Benzophenone was purchased from J&K Scientific. Carboxymethyl chitosan and urea was purchased from Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Factory. Nickel nitrate hexahydrate, magnesium nitrate hexahydrate and aluminum nitrate hexahydrate was purchased from Sinopharm Group Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts The NiMgAl-CMC-in situ catalyst was prepared by an in situ method. For a typical run, 4.0 g CMC was first dissolved in 200 mL of deionized water with sufficient stirring. Subsequently, the corresponding amount of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, Mg(NO3)2·6H2O and Al(NO3)3·9H2O with the molar ratio of Ni: Mg: Al = 1:4:2 was dissolved in 20 mL of deionized water, together with urea [n(urea) = 3 n(Mn+)]. Afterwards, the above solution was slowly added into the CMC solution. Following that, the resulted suspension was stirred at 125 °C for 5 h. After completion, the suspension was filtered, and the obtained solid was washed several times with deionized water until the pH = 7. The green precipitation thus obtained was named as Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-LDH-in situ. Finally, the solid was calcined at 500 °C for 2 h to gain the Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-LDO-in situ precursor, which was then reduced under H2 atmosphere at 600 °C for 2 h. The final catalyst was denoted as Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ. In addition, Ni1Mg2Al1-CMC-in situ, Ni1Mg3Al1-CMC-in situ and Ni1Mg5Al2-CMC-in situ were prepared by the same method using different molar ratios. Ni1Mg4Al2-in situ was prepared by the same method in the absence of CMC. Ni/Mg4Al2-imp was prepared using an impregnation method with the same Ni/Mg/Al ratio as Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ. The experimental details for the preparation of these catalysts are described in the Supporting Information. 2.3 Catalyst characterizations The BET specific surface area, pore volume and pore size distribution, and nitrogen adsorption-desorption curves were all measured using a Micromeritics Tristar II 3020 specific surface and structure analyzer. Before the sample was tested, it was dried in an oven at 150 °C for 12 h to remove a small amount of residual water from the catalyst. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were tested on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation at 40 kV and 40 mA over a 10–80 range. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) of the prepared catalysts was observed using a FEI Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN microscope operating at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. Temperature programmed hydrogen reduction (H2-TPR) was tested on a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 instrument. The sample (50 mg) was first pretreated in an Ar gas stream (50 mL min−1) at 200 °C for 2 h to remove adsorbed water and impurities. After cooling to 50 °C, the catalyst was heated to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 under a 10% H2-Ar (50 mL min−1) gas mixture. NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was also performed on this Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 instrument. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was carried out on a PHI 1600 spectrometer using a Mg Kα source, and the C1s signal (284.8 eV) is used as a standard. 2.4 Catalyst activity evaluation Selective hydrogenation of benzophenone was carried out in a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave equipped with a mechanical stirrer and an electrical heating system. In a typical run, 1.50 g benzophenone, 0.15 g catalyst and 60 mL ethanol were successively added into the autoclave. The autoclave was then sealed, filled and evacuated successively with H2 three times, and then pressurized to 2.5 MPa. The reaction mixture was stirred in 400 rpm at 100 °C for 40 min. After completion, it was cooled to room temperature and separated by magnetism. The products were analyzed using an Agilent 7820A gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a hydrogen flame ion detector, and subjected to structural identification by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) using a Thermo Fisher Trace 1300 + ISQ LT. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Selection of catalysts To evaluate the performance of the resulting catalysts, selective hydrogenation of benzophenone was carried out and the results are shown in Table 1 . Considering that the ratio of metal precursors has a key influence on their performance, the exploration of the ratio was first performed. Notably, the catalysts prepared under various Ni:Mg:Al mass ratios (1:2:1, 1:3:1, 1:4:2, and 1:5:2) showed distinct catalytic performances. The highest yield (93.8%) of diphenylmethanol was obtained with >99.9% benzophenone conversion when using the Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ as catalyst. In contrast, Ni1Mg4Al2-in situ and Ni/Mg4Al2-imp can only achieve 85.7% and 43.3% conversion of benzophenone, respectively, much lower than that of Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ. Therefore, we speculate that the strategy with CMC as template can promote the formation of high BET specific surface area and the dispersion of Ni species, thereby contributing to a better catalytic activity. Thus, Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ is chosen as the best catalyst for further investigation. Considering stability is a key character for catalysts, reusability of Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ and Ni/Mg4Al2-imp was then evaluated. As shown in Fig. 1 A, Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ can be recycled for at least ten runs without appreciable activity loss. In contrast, the conversion of benzophenone distinctly decreased from 43.3% to 30.7% when Ni/Mg4Al2-imp catalyst was used (Fig. 1B). Furthermore, Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ also showed the best stability among the catalysts reported previously (see Table S1). It is suggested that the introduction of CMC can enhance the interaction between the active Ni and support, suppressing the aggregation of Ni and thus accounting for the excellent stability of Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ. To confirm this speculation, we carried out necessary characterizations. 3.2 Characterization of catalysts The physicochemical properties of these nickel-based catalysts were investigated and the results are shown in Table 2 . The BET specific surface area and pore volume of Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ are 194.3 m2 g−1 and 0.51 cm3 g−1, remarkably higher than those of Ni1Mg4Al2-in situ and Ni/Mg4Al2-imp. Furthermore, Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ also showed the highest hydrogen adsorption capacity, metal dispersion and metal specific surface area among these catalysts. Particularly, its metal surface area is 2.58 and 28.30 times to that of Ni1Mg4Al2-in situ and Ni/Mg4Al2-imp, demonstrating its more active sites. In addition, NH3-TPD results of Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ and Ni1Mg4Al2-in situ (Fig. S1) reveal that the addition of CMC has little effect on the base-acid properties of the catalysts, in agreement with the product selectivity results (Table 1). Thus, the in situ method and the addition of CMC can significantly improve the dispersion and exposure of the active Ni species, resulting in its excellent catalytic performance. The N2 adsorption-desorption curves, as well as the pore size distribution, of Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ, Ni1Mg4Al2-in situ and Ni/Mg4Al2-imp are exhibited in Fig. 2 . These catalysts showed the type IV isotherm at relative pressure of P/P0>0.4, together with a H3-type hysteresis loop (Fig. 2A) [50], suggesting a dominant mesoporous structure. However, for their pore size distributions, Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ has a wider range than that of Ni1Mg4Al2 -in situ (Fig. 2B), further indicating that CMC has an important effect on the formation of pore structure. In addition, the in-situ prepared catalysts show better characters in the pore size and BET specific surface area than the catalyst prepared by the impregnation method, indicating that the addition of CMC and the in situ method is more favorable for achieving high BET specific surface area and porosity. XRD patterns of Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ, Ni1Mg4Al2-in situ and Ni/Mg4Al2-imp catalysts before and after reduction are shown in Fig. 3 . As can be seen from Fig. 3A, the peaks at 2θ = 37.3°, 43.3°, 62.9°, 75.4° and 79.4° in the calcined catalysts are ascribed to the characteristic diffraction peaks of NiO [51]. The disappearance of these peaks after reduction, together with the formation of Ni0 characteristic diffraction peaks (JCPDS:04-0850) at 2θ = 44.3°, 51.8° and 76.4°, indicates that the NiO is reduced to Ni0 during the reduction process and Ni0 is the active species for these nickel-based catalysts (Fig. 3B) [5,52,53]. In Fig. 3B, the peak of Ni0 in the Ni/Mg4Al2-imp catalyst (Fig. 3B a) is significantly narrower and sharper than that of Ni0 in Ni1Mg4Al2-in situ (Fig. 3B b), indicating that the particle size of Ni0 in the Ni/Mg4Al2-imp catalyst is larger. Notably, the characteristic diffraction peak of Ni0 in the Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ catalyst is relatively wider than those of Ni1Mg4Al2-in situ and Ni/Mg4Al2-imp, attributed to smaller size and better dispersion of the Ni nanoparticles in Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ [54], demonstrating the advantage of the addition of CMC and the in situ synthetic method. The morphology and structure of the fresh and used Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ, Ni1Mg4Al2-in situ and Ni/Mg4Al2-imp are depicted in Fig. 4 . It is obvious that the Ni nanoparticles in the fresh Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ are uniformly distributed and their particle sizes are limited in a small range (around 4.96 nm, Fig. 4a). Notably, the used Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ still shows a uniform distribution and small range (about 6.80 nm) for Ni nanoparticles even after ten cycles (Fig. 4b), suggesting that the interaction between the active Ni and support can markedly inhibit the aggregation of Ni nanoparticles. This further elucidates the reason of excellent stability of Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ. In contrast, the average sizes of the Ni nanoparticles in the Ni1Mg4Al2-in situ catalyst increase from 5.84 to 8.16 nm during the reaction (Fig. 4c and 4d), demonstrating the effect of CMC. Notably, the Ni nanoparticles in the fresh Ni/Mg4Al2-imp catalyst clearly tend to aggregate into a bulk structure with disorder distribution (Fig. 4e), and the used Ni/Mg4Al2-imp catalyst becomes more serious agglomeration after five runs (Fig. 4f). These comparable results consistently demonstrate that the addition of CMC in the in situ method can enhance the interaction between the active Ni and support, thereby promoting the uniform dispersion of Ni nanoparticles, resulting in its high activity and stability. On the basis of previous reports, the difference on reduction temperature can be ascribed to the existence of different kind of Ni species in the nickel-based catalysts [3,55–57]. Therefore, H2-TPR was performed to study the reducibility of the Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-LDO-in situ, Ni1Mg4Al2-LDO-in situ and Ni/Mg4Al2-LDO-imp precursors, and the profiles are exhibited in Fig. 5 . It should be noticed that the reduction peaks at 424, 435 and 452 °C can be attributed to the reduction of bulk NiO or free NiO in the prepared precursors, indicating the existence of weak interaction between NiO and support. Whereas, the peaks at 685, 693 and 704 °C correspond to the peaks of NiO that having a strong interaction with support [54,58]. It is obvious that the reduction peaks of Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-LDO-in situ slightly shifted to higher temperatures compared to those of Ni1Mg4Al2-LDO-in situ and Ni/Mg4Al2-LDO-imp, which indicates that the interaction between the active Ni and support can be enhanced while using an in situ method and the addition of CMC, and then result in its excellent stability. XPS spectra of Ni 2p3/2 for the reduced Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ and Ni/Mg4Al2-imp samples are shown in the Fig. 6 . As well known, Ni mainly has two valence states: metallic Ni0 and oxidized Ni2+ [4,59]. The peaks at 852.29 and 852.77 eV are attributed to Ni0 [60], and the peaks at 854.63 and 855.87 eV with satellite peaks at 860.96 and 861.27 eV can be ascribed to NiO species [61]. Notably, the determined 2p peaks for Ni species in Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ slightly shift to higher binding energies in comparison to those of Ni/Mg4Al2-imp. Such observed shifts may be attributed to the addition of CMC and indicative of the presence of an increased interaction between the active Ni and support [62], in good agreement with the H2-TPR results. 4 Conclusions Thus, a facile strategy for the fabrication of stable nickel-based LDHs catalysts via an in situ method was first developed in this work. Carboxymethyl chitosan was applied as a biomass template to coordinate with the nickel ions so that to avoid the rapid precipitation of the nickel ions during the formation of LDHs. The obtained in situ nickel-based LDHs catalysts showed large BET specific surface area, high dispersion of Ni and hydrogen adsorption capacity. A Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ catalyst revealed excellent catalytic activity and stability in benzophenone selective hydrogenation. TEM, H2-TPR and XPS characterizations demonstrated that the introduction of CMC in the in situ method can not only improve the dispersion of the active Ni, but also enhance the interaction between Ni and support, which can effectively inhibit the agglomeration of the active Ni in the reaction process. coredata.dc:description: Herein, we have facilely fabricated a series of novel nickel-based layered double hydroxides catalysts with carboxymethyl chitosan as sacrificial template using an in situ method. A Ni1Mg4Al2-CMC-in situ catalyst shows excellent catalytic performance in benzophenone selective hydrogenation. The addition and elimination of CMC was confirmed to play an important role in increasing the BET specific surface area and improving the dispersion of the active Ni species. Furthermore, the strong interaction between the active species and support was also enhanced, simultaneously. These behaviors are believed to promote the catalytic efficiency and suppress the unexpected Ni aggregation. Considering its good catalytic performance and low cost, it has vast potential significance in the fabrication of nickel-based layered double hydroxides catalysts for catalytic reactions.
coredata.dc:title: In situ fabrication of nickel-based layered double hydroxides catalysts with carboxymethyl chitosan as biomass template for hydrogenation
